DOC.TEXT: American Airlines has reached agreement with Eastern Airlines to buy Latin American routes and certain other assets from the struggling carrier for $471 million. The deal, announced Tuesday, will give American Airlines 20 destinations in 15 Central and South American countries. In addition, American gets the Miami-London route authority of Eastern's sister carrier, Continential Airlines, as well as Eastern's routes from Miami and Tampa, Fla., to Toronto. Plus, American gets Eastern slots at John F. Kennedy Airport in New York, at Miami International Airport and San Juan, Puerto Rico.

The government reported a 0.4 percent rise in consumer inflation last month despite a drop in gasoline costs. November's seasonally adjusted increase in the Consumer Price Index, which translated into an annual inflation rate of 4.9 percent, followed a brisk 0.5 percent rise in October and relatively modest hikes from June through September, the Labor Department reported Tuesday.

Housing starts dropped 4.7 percent in November, pulled down by a big dip in multifamily construction, the government said. The Commerce Department said Tuesday that new houses and apartments were built at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.36 million units in November, down from 1.43 million units in October. Total housing starts for the first 11 month of the year were down 6.5 percent from the same period of 1988. Applications for building permits, a barometer of future housing activity, edged down 1.7 percent in November after rising 2.8 percent in October.

The nation's dominant long-distance telephone company, American Telephone & Telegraph Co., announced it will cut basic, daytime interstate rates an average of 1.3 percent Jan. 1. Evening rates will drop an average of 2.0 percent. AT&T said Tuesday the lowered rates reflect reduced expenses, mainly from reduced fees that AT&T will pay in 1990 to local telephone companies for access to local exchanges. AT&T said the reductions were necessary under changes earlier this year in the Federal Communications Commission's regulation of long-distance charges. The FCC now imposes caps on AT&T's long-distance rates based on the company's long-distance expenses, as opposed to a preset rate of return.

Federal antitrust regulators have cleared investor Carl C. Icahn to acquire a bigger stake in USX Corp., the Federal Trade Commission said. The agency said Tuesday it had granted Icahn early termination of the waiting period required under federal law to ensure that certain mergers and acquisitions do not violate antitrust law.

Michael R. Quinlan, president and chief executive of McDonald's Corp., will succeed Fred L. Turner as chairman of the world's largest restaurant chain on March 31, the company has announced. Quinlan, 45, said Tuesday he wants to put the Golden Arches in China and that McDonald's customers will likely see more dinner-type entrees added to the menu in coming years. Turner, 56, will become senior chairman and continue as chairman of the board's executive committee, McDonald's said.

The Environmental Protection Agency said it has obtained court agreements calling for polluters to foot estimated cleanup costs totaling $69.5 million at nine hazardous waste sites targeted by the Superfund program. In addition, the polluters involved also will reimburse the government $11.6 million for past costs, EPA officials said Tuesday at briefing on recent Superfund enforcement cases.

President Bush worked toward a final version of a 1991 budget plan that sources said would include a record $1.24 trillion in spending. Meanwhile, Bush on Tuesday signed a deficit-fighting bill trimming the budget for this year. Despite Bush's ``no new taxes'' vows, the new federal budget also is likely to propose a series of new excise taxes, including a fee on the sale of certain recreational equipment and vehicles, said officials who spoke on the condition of anonymity.

Federal engineers have upgraded an investigation of a possible steering deficiency in the 1988 Chevrolet Beretta, the government said. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration also said Tuesday it was investigating reports of exploding heating systems in Coachmen Industries recreational vehicles and of cruise control failures in the Ford Taurus and its twin, the Mercury Sable.

Stock prices continued to sag Tuesday amid persistent worries about the future course of the economy. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 1.92 to 2,695.61, extending its loss over the past four sessions to 65.48 points. The dollar finished slightly higher. Bond prices were mixed and Treasury bill yields rose. Forecasts for a frosty weekend in Florida's citrus belt drove orange juice futures prices up sharply, while grains and soybeans, livestock and meat, and precious-metals futures were mixed.
